text: every day the typical New York City
apartment building can go through
hundreds of kilowatt hours of
electricity most of New York's comes
from generators powered by fossil fuels
like oil or natural gas i'm jim dwyer
I'm a columnist with the times this is
my building about four years ago myself
and some neighbors try to figure out a
way we could make our own energy right
here on the spot what natural resources
do we have here in the city well we
don't have ocean floor beds or desert
sands with big fissures of oil
underneath them we do have a lot of wind
and we have acres and acres of roof
enough solar energy falls on New York
City every day to supply more
electricity than the city can use it's a
crowded City but these roofs are our
Great Plains and a largely untapped
source of energy our building now gets
up to ten percent of its power needs
during the day from the Sun enough to
supply things like the elevator the
laundry room and the hallway lights how
it comes through this comes into what we
call an inverter this takes the DC power
and it transforms it to AC power solar
is not a new technology but it is
expensive and many government incentives
to help pay for it have been geared to
smaller installations or simply don't
apply to cooperative apartment houses so
we dug around and we found that there
was in fact tax credits in the form of
25% essentially of the cost of the
installation and the purchase of solar
panels to homeowners who were going to
put in about 10 kilowatt kilowatts of of
panels but if you're a multifamily
apartment building it's hardly a drop in
the bucket so what we thought we might
do is to see if we could encourage the
state to broaden the tax code to cover
50 kilowatts Assemblymember Herman
Farrell and state senator Dean Skelos
sponsored a bill that made the tax
credits big enough to help an apartment
house and governor Spitzer signed it
July third
late November crews started unloading
our new panels we're one of the first
private cooperatives in the city to put
in a solar array of the size these solar
panels have a 25-year warranty we expect
a lifetime of close to 50 years we
wanted these panels to work ecologically
and economically so we got a grant from
the state the tax credit and a
low-interest loan we think the
electricity they generate will pay off
that loan inside of ten years for no
more money than we would have paid con
Edison or any commercial supplier and
after that its solar gravy free energy
for the life of the panels so now after
four years of planning scheming and
number crunching we think we figured it
out yes you can make solar power play in
Manhattan may not be the arithmetic that
appeals to hedge fund operators or even
to very strict and rigorous economists
but for us it works and New York has
been generating electricity through
other means for more than a century it's
used oil it's used coal we think this
may be the start of another way
